Sacrifice of G. R. Man, Comrades for Science Unsurpassed in All
the Annals of War; Veterans, City Prepare to Honor His Memory
G.R. Herald Aug 26, 1928
By JOHN M. KELLY

PRIVATE X. Y., looking down from his abode in Valhalla,
must be smiling now as he contemplates the zeal of hero-
admiring former comrades of Spanish war days and of a
grateful city which soon will confer upon him a post-
humous honor he shunned while living.

Private X. Y. for 26 years
was the unknown hero of
science's battle on yellow
fever, the deadly curse of
Cuba, before which had fal-
len by the thousands brave
men who had volunteered to
face the Spanish bullets fol-
lowing the sinking of the
Maine in '98--the scourge
which had claimed two-thirds
of the general staff of Maj.
Gen. Wood.

Private X. Y. was one of the
heroic six who had volunteered to
permit himself to be bitten by the
deadly stegomyia mosquito--to offer
his life blood as a human labora-
tory in sacrifice to his fellow man.

Private X. Y., an appreciative
government learned 27 years later,
was Pvt. William H. Dean of Grand
Rapids, a member of Troop B,
United States cavalry. And Sergt.
Dean--he was promoted before
leaving the service--for 27 years
had suffered in silence, uncomplain-
ing, paying the price of an act of
heroism that will live forever as
one of the most dramatic epics in
the annals of medicine.
Grand Rapids will dedicate to this

hero the new William H. Dean
bridge that spans the river at Ful-
ton st. But had it not been almost
[unclear] accident, the story of William
H. Dean's heroism would never have
been known; he would have been
remembered only by relatives and
close friends as an honest work-
ingman who struggled valiantly
for an existence despite a heart af-
fliction that caused him untold
hours of agony and physicians' and
hospital bills for treatment of which
proved a constant drain upon his
income.

Visualize Cuba in 1901 as de-
scribed by Dr. Wilmer Krusen, now
director of public health for the
city of Philadelphia, in a magazine
article that led to first knowledge
after 26 years that even Dean's par-
ents had of the deed of their son.

Four men, medical officers of the
American army, Dr. Krusen wrote
in the American magazine, were
gathered together in Quenmados on
a hot tropical night.

“They were seated about a table.
It was a grim business they were
on. Their browned faces were grave
and set. The Spaniards had been
routed and cleared from the land.
Gen. Leonard Wood and his troops
were in possession of Cuba.
The Hush of Death

“But though banners which
hailed this victory of American
arms still flaunted gaily in the
streets of New York, and Chicago
and San Francisco, the hush of
Death was over Cuba, and over that
little group in the hot room at
Quemados.

“This death was an invisible yel-
low assassin. Passing over the
squalor of the native slums and
leaving them almost unscathed, it
had descended upon the American
quarters. Indeed, it had invaded
the very seat of American control,
and had taken a third of the gov-
ernor general's staff. Every hos-
pital bed was filled by an Ameri-
can lad whose face and chest had
turned to the yellow of gold and
who writhed in delirium.

“Yellow fever--that unsolved
mystery of four centuries--had
Cuba in its grip!

“For a month these four medi-
cal men--Walter Reed, James Car-
roll, Jesse W. Lazear and Aristides
Agramonte--had been at it night
and day, seeking a chink in the
armor of the yellow curse.

“Reed was the directing genius.
He had spent 14 years at the bed-
side of the sick on the western
plains and mountains. He had
doctored in New York's slums. He
had studied disease at first hand
and under some of the best mas-
ters that America could boast.

“Thus far, failure had stalked
the commission in its efforts to
determine the cause of the disease.
Medical Society
Pays Tribute to
Dean's Sacrifice
The Kent County Medical society,
in recognition of Pvt. William H.
Dean's sacrifice in the interest of
humanity and science, recently took
official cognizance of his heroism
in the form of the following letter,
addressed to Dean's parents:
“This letter is to acquaint you
of the recent action taken by the
Kent County Medical society upon
the occasion of the death of your
son, William H. Dean.
“His courage on the battle-field
during the Spanish-American war,
was only excelled by his supreme
bravery at its close in offering him-
self in the great struggle of medical
science against a mysterious and
fatal disease, and his name will
be historical among those martyrs
who have given their lives in the
interest of humanity and for the
advancement of science.
“The Kent County Medical so-
ciety therefore extends to you their
sincere sympathy for the untimely
death of your hero kin, and as-
sures you of their hearty approval
of the city commission's plan to commemorate his heroic deed by
naming in his memory the new
Fulton street bridge, “The William
H. Dean Bridge,” and furthermore,
by official action the committee has
been instructed to write to our local
representatives in senate and house,
urging that suitable recognition of
his heroism and death be taken by
the government of the United
States.

Very sincerely,
“Charles V. Crane, M. D.,
“Geo. L. Bond, M. D.,
“John M. Whalen, M. D.

Meanwhile Havana had been
scoured and cleaned; its houses had
been disinfected, its streets washed
down and its alleys fumigated.
Seemingly the more cleanly the
city became, the more virulent be-
came the scourge.
One Chance Left

“One chance only was left, a
chance which the whole medical
world held in ridicule. In Havana
there was a Cuban physician, Dr.
Carlos Finlay. For 20 years Dr.
Finlay had been insisting that a
certain kind of mosquito was re-
sponsible for yellow fever. Finlay
had made tireless experiments to
prove his theory, but every one of
his experiments had failed.

“But Reed, in his study, had dis-
covered a fact that Finlay had
overlooked. Following a case of
yellow fever, it was invariably two
weeks or longer before new cases
appeared. This indicated that the
mosquito--if it was the carrier--
had to go days after biting a yel-
low fever patient before it became
dangerous to other human beings.
Reed believed that Finlay in his
experiments had not given the
mosquitoes time.

“So in Quemados, that hot night,
those four medical men discussed
mosquitoes. The task confronting
them was to prove, as Finlay con-
tended, that yellow fever was car-
ried by mosquitoes only, and that,
among all the 800 varieties of mos-
quitoes, the stegomyia mosquito
alone was a carrier of the disease.

“And this task, as fate would
have it, was augmented by a hide-
ous circumstance: Animals do not
‘take’ yellow fever. So far as was
known, the only living creature who
suffered yellow fever was man!
Father of 5 Speaks

“Reed was pale as he outlined his
theory of Finlay's failure. It was
Carroll, the father of five children,
who spoke out:

“‘That means’, he queried blunt-
ly, ‘that to prove this mosquito
theory, somebody, a man, has to
offer himself for experiment?’

“Reed nodded. Lazear nodded, a
gleam in his eyes. If healthy non-
immune men, would let themselves
be bitten by stegomyia mosquitoes
which two weeks or more before
had bitten yellow fever sufferers,
the Finlay-Reed theory would be
proved or disproved by the result.

“To make the experiment with-
out flaw, at least a dozen men would
have to be bitten!

“‘You can count on me for one’,
said Carroll.
“‘And on me’, said Lazear.

“Agramonte was immune and
therefore useless. Reed was under
orders to return immediately to
Washington.

“The meeting broke up. In a day
or two Reed left, and Carroll and
Lazear began their experiments, of
which all medical history contains
no more heroic record.

“Together with the seven men
nameless in the records, Lazear let
the mosquitoes suck the blood of
his arms. The days passed.
Strangely enough, nothing devel-
oped. The doctor and his seven
men remained in health. After all,
was Reed mistaken?

“‘You tried too soon,’ Carroll
argued. ‘Now it's my turn.’

“He waited until almost three
weeks had gone by. By this time,
if Reed was right, the yellow fever
blood in the imprisoned insects had
ripened to deadly virulence. Carroll
then had Lazear select the most
dangerous looking mosquito in his
whole collection.
A Sublime Act

“This huge insect, brave Carroll
let alight on his wrist, on the un-
der part where the skin was thin
and veins near the surface, and
watched without a tremor as it
drank its fill of his blood.

“‘If there is anything to this
mosquito theory,’ he wrote back to
Reed that night, ‘I should get a
good dose of yellow fever.’

“In a few days the fever was up-
on him. Lazear and Agramonte
stood by.

“‘Friends,’ said Dr. Carroll and
smiled, ‘this is the proudest mo-
ment of my life. I may prove some-
thing for humanity.’

“To make sure that it wasn't
malaria he had, Dr. Carroll him-
self went to the laboratory, took
a sample of his own blood and ex-
amined it under the microscope.
No malaria was there.

“Next morning, Lazear carried
him to the yellow fever ward, and
there, near to death, Carroll lay for
days. Once Lazear thought his
heart had stopped; but Carroll's
fine constitution rallied. Eventual-
ly, he recovered, but a serious
heart trouble followed as a direct
result of the fever. He died several
years later.

“Following Carroll. Private Wil-
liam H. Dean of Grand Rapids,
Mich., let himself be bitten by four
mosquitoes, including the one that
had downed Carroll. Soon he, too,
was tossing with delirium.

“But Lazear, as he fought for the
lives of his charges, wasn't sure yet.
There was a possibility, he rea-
soned, that Carroll and Dean might
have exposed themselves to infec-
tion in other ways. As he pondered
over this a mosquito of the deadly
species alighted on his wrist. He
was about to brush off the insect,
when deliberately he restrained his
hand.

“All about him were yellow fever
patients. This mosquito was living
among them. Lazear let the insect
drink its fill. Four days later, to-
ward evening, he had his first
chill. A languor came over him, but
he fought it back. All that night
and on to dawn he sat at his desk,
that he might give to the world a
written record of his investigations.

“Steadily he noted his symptoms.
The task done, at last, he staggered
weakly with the manuscript to
Carroll, placed the paper in his
hands, and took to his bed. He died
at the end of the sixth day.
Apogee of Courage

since the first war, in all the pages
of literature, I believe there is no

Dean is shown as he appeared
shortly after enlisting in the U. S.

The last picture ever taken of
Pvt. Dean, snapped at a picnic of
the plasterers' union at Meyers
lake in 1925, is reproduced in No. 9.

The new bridge across Grand
river at Fulton st., named Dean
bridge in honor of the hero of '98
is seen in No. 1. The family group,
No. 4, taken before the Spanish-
American war, shows, standing,
left to right, Dean's brother, Royal
M., of Los Angeles, who served with
him in Cuba; William H. Dean; a
sister, Mrs. Daisy Field, of Grand
Rapids; seated, Mrs. Mable Brokaw
of Chicago, a sister; Mrs. Norman
C. Wood, his mother; Mrs. Laura
Van Hof of Grand Rapids, and Miss
Flossie Field.

In No. 6 are some of the mem-
bers of the committee from Guy V.
Henry camp, Spanish-American
war veterans, who have been active
in arranging the dedication pro-
gram. They are: Left to right, Past
Commanders Arnold Claver and
William K. Hiler, Commander Fred
Kuemmerle, Historian C. A. Boone
and Chairman William A. Gould.
Past Commander W. H. Zylstra.
Walter H. Brooks and Stanley J.
McMahon, other members of the
camp's committee, were absent
when picture was taken. McMahon
volunteered to make the same sac-
rifice that Dean did, but was not
called upon to do so.

Mr. and Mrs. Norman C. Wood,

and courage than this tale of La-
